comments.commentBody:
"The Factor" is okay. It depends on the owners taste. I bet the one who named it might have lots to tell about the name... you agree?

Horseracing

PIER gave me pause, too, but once i conquered it the image was delightfully absurd. can't you just see all those blind men marching off the end of a pier into the sea like all of the names and numbers lining up to be forgotten from one's memory? a lesser prosodist would simply have said "like lemmings."

The greatest wealth is .....to need the least.

He's gone to considerable lengths to prolong his life and the lives of others. The real measure of a man is not how well he takes care of himself, but what he does for others.

No one has taken note of the triptych that fully expresses life: Body, Mind and Spirit. Pity those who lack any one of them.

So many mean comments pass here for consideration. It's hard to believe we are one family .....man.

Maybe the light will yet come....

I agree with your column 100%.  This is something I have wondered about myself.  Why does the United States have such a long history of supporting dictatorships.  We talk about human rights, but only when it doesn't get in the way of own political ambitions or as in the Middle East in the way of our oil supply.  Thank goodness these people have the guts and determination to try and make their countries a better place with freedoms that we take for granted.

Does supporting corrupt regimes make the US government itself corrupt?

The answer is, yes it does.

Gosh, Mr. Friedman, I've been writing the same thing for months if not years, & so have many other commenters to New York Times columns. We're glad you're catching on. Now, since you have so many friends in high places, do get one of them to scooch your column into the President's daily reading list.

I think President Obama is a smart guy, so you might think he would have noticed on his own the deep irony inherent in his international policy (I guess there's an overarching policy -- hard to tell). Evidently, though, the schizophrenic nature of our relationships with tyrants is something Obama chooses not to see. So it would be good if he understood that a lot of us here & in Afghanistan don't suffer from that particular blind spot.

To "lead" Afghanistan, George Bush brought us Muammar Gaddafi in a nicer hat. Barack Obama has chosen to supply Karzai & his cronies, at the expense of Afghans & Americans, an endless supply of those hats. Our support of the second-most corrupt government in the world is a stain on our national character as indelible as the stains of slavery & racism. That support is not even callously expedient. It didn't work in Viet Nam; it didn't work in Iran; it didn't work in Egypt. When are the people we elect to lead this country ever going to get it?

The principal of self-governance is really very simple. The fact that one president after another ignores it or rationalizes it away suggests that they don't really believe in democracy, for other countries -- or for us.

Americans have not lost confidence in the President & Congress because we think "there is too much government." We've lost confidence because we know the government we have is unprincipled, reckless and venal.

The Constant Weader at www.RealityChex.com

comments.userDisplayName: Phil in the mountains of Kyushu
comments.commentBody:
Thanks for these Q's you raise on this day particularly.

While you ask about people of North Africa and the Mideast rising up against corrupt and despotic governments -- such corruption and despotism as the U.S. has supported -- you do so on exactly the 175th anniversary of the fall of the Alamo.

Back then, as Fess Parker and Buddy Ebsen fans will recall, the improvised garrison fell just before dawn as the Mexican federal forces overwhelmed them. But it's worth noting, in light of your good questions today on how democratization occurs, that the battle at the former church mission in Bexar was not at all a racial fight. It was part of a series of democratization movements across the Texas provinces -- with often more-largely Hispanic locals also fighting against the federal government in faraway Mexico City.

They all were seeking more freedom from remote and centralized force -- just as peoples across the Arab and Muslim world in North Africa and the Mideast are restive against all that corruption and despotism they've too long faced.

So thanks for raising these questions. Would you please follow up with inquiry as to which U.S. corporate interests for decades now have kept obliging the U.S. to be mired so deeply so consistently on the wrong side of history?

May I suggest a couple of other questionable regimes we support? First of all, there’s Iraq, where corruption is synonymous with government. It’s anybody’s guess into whose pockets a few billion dollars have disappeared. It is also looking more and more like an authoritarian government as Maliki now uses security forces to suppress demonstrations. And then there is Saudi Arabia, which just announced that demonstrations will not be tolerated.
It’s time to cut our losses and bail out of the Middle East, we sure can use the money back home to cover some of the draconian cuts being made by the Tea Party driven GOP.
As long as the military-industrial complex and its minions, the US Congress, put profits before people, there's little hope of redirecting those billions.

I wholeheartedly agree. The brilliance of the Obama Administration's approach in Egypt and Tunisia is that our President cast off the old way of doing business. In the face of popular uprisings against dictators in those two countries, President Obama neither became a saber rattling cheerleading spouting off about "regime change," nor attempted to prop up the dictators in the name of security. Instead, President Obama overruled his advisers, and ignored critics on both the left and the right, and decided to stake a public position in support of the will of the people of those countries, and to privately use diplomacy to curb any inclination by the governments of Egypt and Tunisia to violently crush those uprisings.

I agree that we need to find a way to implement a similar approach in Afghanistan and Pakistan. Unfortunately, the Obama Administration's decision to step up drone attacks in Pakistan and to increase troop levels in Afghanistan were the wrong things to do. Those approaches simply prop up corrupt dictatorships and further alienate and anger the people of those countries. Instead, we need to make clear that we will strike at any terrorist organizations that pose a serious direct threat to us, but also reduce our military presence in both Afghanistan and Pakistan and shift our focus to supporting the will of the people in those countries.

http://www.winningprogressive.org

http://www.facebook.com...

But after the corrupt crony capitalist Arab regimes are replaced, what will remain? Even if initially democratic, these will be very young, undereducated countries with high population growth rates likely for many years to come. A pervasive religion that suppresses that talents of women. Enough oil money floating around to keep income expectations higher than in places like east Asia, therefore making the region unable to compete in the cheapest-labor-on-earth market.

In short, it will be a place where economic hopes and expectations will be unlikely to be met. I don't know how that will all play out, but the economic realities will leave the region as fertile territory for terror and dictators.

One has to ask what forces of capitalism were busy backing the totalitarian regimes? But whilst we know them as household brands we don't dare light up the sky and rebel. That would be anti-stifling. No we prefer to buy a Lexus, attend an uneventful congregation of coveted desires, belong to a club without virtue, ride the success train to nowhere's ville on the backs of our competitors ,and go about as if our world is oh so important. We really are not so smart as lucky. And we are watching it slip away as extremism takes hold here. The extremes of ignorance are so fraught with danger that we hold to the untested truth that what we refer to as freedom in a highly weighted world of measurements will sustain our way of life. It won't. And neither will it be good enough for the vaunted fledgling democracies we cheer on in the Arab Middle East. But today we cheer from the sidelines and well we should. We have no moral superiority when we are lost in our complicity. Don't ask your neighbor. Ask yourself.

Interesting; initially reports from Libya were about educated youngsters who want democracy and do not accept to be starved by their self-indulging leader, though lately the reports are about rebel armies which oppose the government. Are we talking about the same people here, or did the tone change because democracy in Libya means rising oil prices?

Can we all hope that reason and common sense prevail?  In that case, the consolidation of wealth among the few (whether they be autocrats or bankers) will be seen as a destabilizing influence and the sharing of resources a stabilizing force.  No matter where it occurs.

I'd also like to see the $110b spent here. And I'd like it to go to students who live in America. Oh it will rankle you so much to hear that you won't print it but we have been educating Chinese, Japanese, Indians and Arabs for decades to the detriment of our own children. Walk down the halls of any bureaucracy and you will hear a variety of languages including Russian and whatever the gibberish it is the Indians speak. But the movie title "Whatever happened to Bob" is more about whatever happened to American students? Tom, you're too smug. You write as if you really live what you see, and believe that this is what you always knew. Your kind is really just a liberal arts degree away from a factory job.

I have been reading what you write for the past 30+ yrs, and over time I recognized a powerful pattern in your writings:
Your deep analysis has been 100% correct after the fact!!!

On the other hand Mr. Friedman, before the fact you gave us the democracy in Iraq on top of an American Tank instead of American Think Tank!!

Hey, what am I talking about; all your analysis ganna be in another book were you are always right after the fact!
One more million dollars for analysis after the fact!
I agree with the conclusions of this article. Bush and Obama have wasted over a trillion tax dollars on for-profit wars in Iraq and Afghanistan, nearly wrecking the economy in the process.

Or, put differently, given the amount we spend on military intervention, we are not getting the bang for our buck we deserve. So, stop throwing money down a hole in the ground. Indeed, why is it, when the military budget is examined in congressional committees, no member of congress asks this question: "Why are we not getting any bang for our buck?"

Dr. Friedman, your $110 Billion Question is one that must be asked and answered by President Obama. And soon. There is no reason today for the United States of America to support - to the tune of hundreds of thousands of troops and $110 Billion - such egregiously corrupt regimes as those in power in Afghanistan and Pakistan. At the same time we are bolstering these Near Eastern countries with money we desperately need here at home to rescue our failing American economy, we are lauding the Arab revolutions in Tunisia, Egypt,and many other Mediterranean rim Arab countries where the saber rattling and cries for democracy and freedom can be heard from Tahrir to Jordan. The writing is on the wall. Mene, mene, tekel, Upharsin ("we have been judged and found wanting").

Bloody civil war is taking place today in Libya under the mad despot, Ghaddafi. That Ghaddafi ordered the bombing of Pan Am 103 over Lockerbie, Scotland in 1988, that Ghaddafi engineered the release of Al-Megrahi, the convicted bomber on death's doorstep in the UK a few years ago (the terrorist has not not yet shuffled off this mortal coil, let's hear it for miracles), are reasons enough for a coalition of willing forces to forcibly pluck the lunatic Colonel off his perch in Tripoli. Is there no one on this earth who can bell the crazy Libyan cat? Is there no one who can scream "the emperor's naked as a jaybird!" about the treasury of US monies being poured down the money pits of Afghanistan and Pakistan for no reason at all? What a strange world and in what strange times we are living, Dr. Friedman! Would that your words would resonate in the Administration's wisest brains and spur our powers-that-be into action to rescue the Libyan people from their demented ruler and rescue the America people from paying taxes that are being poured into bloody unending war and corruption in Afghanistan and Pakistan. Hopefully the realities of the present day surprising and exciting turns of history (cf Tahrir Square) will force America to rethink and redirect her antidiluvian foreign policy, and bring those 110 Billion Dollars back home to do some good in America, instead of doing bad and worse in those two miserable and moribund countries we have been propping up for too long.

Here’s a secret: India is not going to invade Pakistan..... etc, etc.
Phew.It took 40 years for an American Journalist to utter these lines.
Good going America.

Tom-
Like many commentators on the overthrow of regimes in the Middle East, you believe the demonstrators want democracy but in reality they want "representative government". The Muslim majority countries will never become democracies if freedom of religion is included in the definition of democracy. I hope you and other writers will realize this important distinction and continue to applaud the demonstrators for bringing about change to allow elections and have representative governments but please stop referring to them as democracies. Islam is not compatible with the classical definition of democracy.

I totally agree that we should not be sending billions to prop up dictators, but where have you been on this issue? Arming and enriching these thugs is not something dreamed up by President Obama. Where are all the people who were screaming "Cut and Run" whenever anyone dared to suggest leaving?
Turn back time to Feb or Mar two years ago. Let's say the newly elected #44 had decided to stop financial and military support to Afghanistan and Pakistan at that time. I do not believe you would have responded with a column like this one.
The war criminals in the last administration bungled the war in Afghanistan, then neglected it entirely while they dragged us into Iraq. You surely must remember, as you and certain colleagues were passionate cheerleaders for that egregious violation of every convention ever conceived in Geneva. ( A flashback to those turquoise gloves just made me throw up a little.) And again, please do not say that 'nobody'knew. I am in fact one of millions of nobodies who did know.
The ship of state is not an agile creature. Barack Obama inherited these two bungled wars, and he chose not to cut and run. He chose to try to salvage something instead of presiding over a defeat. No one wanted to revisit that nightmare on the roof of the American Embassy in Viet Nam, desperate people climbing over each other into the last helicopters out of Saigon as it fell to the enemy.
Republicans and those who call themselves Independent yet always seem to vote Republican, are now criticizing the president for not cutting and running.
There may be a reason why these revolutions are occuring on Barack Obama's watch. There may be a reason the huge crowds in Tunisia, in Egypt, in Libya, are all chanting "Yes, We Can". For once there is a president in the United States who will not maneuver another Mubarak or Musharaff or Noriega, or Saddam Hussein for that matter, into power.
The Nobel for Peace may have been awarded for potential rather than for achievement, but Barack Obama appears to be fulfilling that potential.

A very timely column indeed; many, many people are asking the same question:  What in the world are we paying for, when the citizens of the Middle East are turning these tides on their own?  The war profiteers do often indeed claim to support and fight for democracy, but should it come about in the most organic way imaginable, they panic.  One way to direct that panic is to continue to support these self same regimes.  But citizens in the US are waking up as well, one hopes.

Finally, finally, someone is making sense! Everyone in India has been screaming this for a while now and they are blue in their face - why is the US still funding Pakistan and ISI, why is it still supplying it weapons when what they really need is humanitarian help. Why is the US still in Afghanistan? Why cannot we let the Afghanis rule by themselves, however corrupt the system may be, maybe just maybe the people will find their voice just like they did in Tunisia and Egypt and Libya, Yemen, Bahrain. Neither Pakistan nor Afghanistan has oil!
While we are at it - maybe we should let the Iraqis rule by themselves too. They are smart sophisticated people, ancient civilization, they can do it.

I agree with almost everything that Friedman has to say except for his extrapolation of the trend to Pakistan. Much like how a person delirious with fever drifts in an out of consciousness, Pakistan has been drifting in and out of democracy. Meanwhile the Pakistani army has been pulling the threads of all the key players in the system, mostly from behind the scene. As a result, the army and its favored child, ISI have been able to create and nurture the impression that they are the only ones that have interest of the country at heart. The politicians are not just corrupt they are incompetent and disorganized. So any uprising that occurs in Pakistan will be against the regime of the day. The army will then proceed to engineer the installation of another puppet government. Needless to say they will ensure that the new regime is 'democratically elected'. Rinse and repeat.

Pakistan is caught in this vicious circle and there appears little chance of its escaping it, except by imploding.
